titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Philip Everett Curtiss Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday December 9, 2018 at 05:47

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Philip Everett Curtiss papers contain writings, printed material, correspondence, and other materials documenting the literary career of Connecticut native Philip Everett Curtiss. Writings consist chiefly of drafts for novels and shorter works, such as articles. Printed materials include journals and clippings containing printed versions of writings by Curtiss and material by, about, and relating to Curtiss. Correspondence consists chiefly of incoming correspondence from publishers, further documenting his literary career. Personal papers include a small number of books inscribed to Curtiss, contracts, manuscript notes, and photographs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Deposited by Philip Everett Curtiss prior to his death in 1964. Gift of Anne Scoville, 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Philip Everett Curtiss Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Philip Everett Curtiss Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Preliminary processing was done on the Philips Everett Curtiss papers at an unknown date. During reprocessing of the collection in 2011, separate runs of alphabetized writings were consolidated into Series I, and printed materials, correspondence, and personal papers were established as Series II, Series III, and Series IV respectively.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Miscrofilm available for portions of the collection.

bioghist.head: Philip Everett Curtiss (1885-1964)
bioghist.p: Philip Everett Curtiss, novelist, legislator, and justice. After a brief career as a newspaper reporter on The Hartford Courant and The Hartford Times , Curtiss returned to his family home in Norfolk, Connecticut, to write. His novels include Between Two Worlds (1916), Mummers in Mufti (1922) and The Gay Conspirators (1924). He turned to politics and law later in life, representing his home district in the General Assembly, as a Republican, from 1941 to 1947 and serving as a trial justice from 1940 to 1955.
Biographical information taken from obituary, New York Times (1923-Current file) ; May 25, 1964; ProQuest Historical Newspapers (accessed 2 March 2011).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Philip Everett Curtiss papers contain writings, printed material, correspondence, and other materials documenting the literary career of Connecticut native Philip Everett Curtiss. Writings consist chiefly of drafts for novels and shorter works, such as articles. Printed materials include journals and clippings containing printed versions of writings by Curtiss and material by, about, and relating to Curtiss. Correspondence consists chiefly of incoming correspondence from publishers, further documenting his literary career. Personal papers include a small number of books inscribed to Curtiss, contracts, manuscript notes, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Writings, 1907-1944. II. Printed Materials, 1901-1940. III. Correspondence, 1903-1932. IV. Personal Papers, 1916-1932.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Writings contains drafts of writings by Curtiss. There are drafts for several novels and for numerous shorter works, chiefly articles. Many shorter works appear on personal letterhead from "809 Asylum Avenue, Hartford, Conn.", presumably dating from his early career as a newspaper reporter, whereas many others are marked from his hometown of Norfolk, where he settled later. A considerable amount of unsorted writings can be found at the end of the alphabetical run of titles and additional writings, also not identified by title, can be found in Series II. Printed Materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Journals and Clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. Printed Materials contains journals and clippings. The journals, arranged alphabetically by title, appear to contain printed versions of writings by Curtiss, whereas the clippings contain material by, about, and relating to Curtiss. For example, there are short writings by Curtiss, reviews of his work by others, brief mentions, and clippings on other topics. Clippings are unsorted.

unittitle.title: Sunday Magazine of the New York Tribune

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. Correspondence appears to consist chiefly of incoming correspondence from publishers, with letters from many of the publishers represented in Series II. Printed Material, including but not limited to The American Magazine , Collier's , Everybody's Magazine , and Harper's . Correspondence is unsorted, with a good portion, if not the bulk, still in original envelopes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. Personal Papers contains books inscribed to Curtiss, contracts with publishers, notes and notebooks, and photographs.

did.unittitle: The Ladies' Home Journal (In Series II)
The Saturday Evening Post (In Series II)
